Dynamics of the heat semigroup on symmetric spaces Lizhen Ji Email: lji@umich.edu, Address: 1834 East Hall, Ann Arbor, MI 48109-1043, USA. Partially supported by NSF grant DMS 0604878 \\ Department of Mathematics, University of Michigan Andreas Weber Email: andreas.weber@math.uni-karlsruhe.de, Address: Englerstr. 2, 76128 Karlsruhe, Germany. \\ Institut f\"ur Algebra und Geometrie, Universit\"at Karlsruhe (TH)

abstract The aim of this paper is to show that the dynamics of [MATH_0] heat semigroups ( [MATH_1] ) on a symmetric space of non-compact type is very different from the dynamics of the [MATH_2] heat semigroups if [MATH_3] . To see this, it is shown that certain shifts of the [MATH_4] heat semigroups have a chaotic behavior if [MATH_5] , and that such a behavior is not possible in the cases [MATH_6] . These results are compared with the corresponding situation for euclidean spaces and symmetric spaces of compact type, where such a behavior is not possible.\\
Keywords: Symmetric spaces of non-compact type, [MATH_7] heat semigroup, spherical functions, Fourier inversion formula, chaotic semigroups.\\[1mm]

The aim of this paper is to show that the dynamics of [MATH_8] heat semigroups ( [MATH_9] ) on a symmetric space [MATH_10] of non-compact type is very different from the dynamics of the [MATH_11] heat semigroup or, more generally, of the [MATH_12] heat semigroups if [MATH_13] . To see this, we prove that certain shifts of the [MATH_14] heat semigroups ( [MATH_15] ) have a chaotic behavior, whereas this is not true for any shift in the [MATH_16] case or, more generally, in the [MATH_17] case if [MATH_18] .\\ The different dynamics of the [MATH_19] heat semigroup and the [MATH_20] heat semigroups is due to the geometry of the symmetric spaces of non-compact type, and it contrasts the fact that the corresponding [MATH_21] heat semigroups on a euclidean space or on a symmetric space of compact type do not have such a chaotic behavior.\\

A related phenomenon is the [MATH_22] -dependence of the [MATH_23] spectrum of a symmetric space of non-compact type [MATH_24] . While the [MATH_25] spectrum of the Laplace operator on euclidean space [MATH_26] equals [MATH_27] for all [MATH_28] , the [MATH_29] spectrum of the Laplace-Beltrami operator on [MATH_30] varies with [MATH_31] .\\ Actually, this fact together with further information on [MATH_32] eigenvalues of the Laplace-Beltrami operator on [MATH_33] will be used in the proof of the results indicated above. \\

The first systematic study of chaotic semigroup started with the paper MR1468101 by Desch, Schappacher, and Webb in 1997 after some papers treating the discrete case appeared, cf. for example MR884467,MR1111569 . Further information could be found in MR2150930,MR2128736,MR1855839,MR2020387,MR1468101,MR1685272,MR1484673 . From these papers we want to mention in particular the paper by Herzog MR1484673 and the one by deLaubenfels, Emamirad, and Grosse-Erdmann MR2020387 where the heat semigroup is studied in a different context.\\
However, it seems that the theory of chaotic dynamical systems in the sense of Devaney as it is used in this paper has not been applied in 'geometric' settings up to now. \\

Our main input from the papers cited above will be two abstract results contained in MR1468101 and MR2128736 which yield a sufficient condition for chaotic behavior. Further important tools from the realm of symmetric spaces that will be needed are the spherical Fourier transform and the corresponding [MATH_34] inversion formula. \\
Similar results as in the case of symmetric spaces of non-compact type are true for non-compact locally symmetric spaces with finite volume, cf. JiWeb:nr .
Heat semigroup on [MATH_35] spaces heat semigroup

In this section [MATH_36] denotes an arbitrary complete Riemannian manifold. The Laplace-Beltrami operator [MATH_37] with domain [MATH_38] (the set of infinitely differentiable functions with compact support) is essentially self-adjoint and hence, its closure [MATH_39] is a self-adjoint operator on the Hilbert space [MATH_40] . Since [MATH_41] is positive, [MATH_42] generates a bounded analytic semigroup [MATH_43] on [MATH_44] which can be defined by the spectral theorem for unbounded self-adjoint operators. The semigroup [MATH_45] is a submarkovian semigroup (i.e., [MATH_46] is positive and a contraction on [MATH_47] for any [MATH_48] ) and we therefore have the following: itemize [(1)] The semigroup [MATH_49] leaves the set [MATH_50] invariant and hence, [MATH_51] may be extended to a positive contraction semigroup [MATH_52] on [MATH_53] for any [MATH_54] . These semigroups are strongly continuous if [MATH_55] and consistent in the sense that [MATH_56] . [(2)] Furthermore, if [MATH_57] , the semigroup [MATH_58] is a bounded analytic semigroup with angle of analyticity [MATH_59] . itemize For a proof of (1) we refer to [Theorem 1.4.1] MR1103113 . For (2) see MR1224619 . In general, the semigroup [MATH_60] needs not be analytic. However, if [MATH_61] has bounded geometry [MATH_62] is analytic in some sector (cf. MR924464,MR1023321 ).

In the following, we denote by [MATH_63] the generator of [MATH_64] and by [MATH_65] the spectrum of [MATH_66] . Furthermore, we will write [MATH_67] for the semigroup [MATH_68] . Because of (2) from above, the [MATH_69] spectrum [MATH_70] has to be contained in the sector [MATH_441]
If we identify as usual the dual space of [MATH_71] , with [MATH_72] , the dual operator of [MATH_73] equals [MATH_74] and therefore we always have [MATH_75] .

There are many different definitions of chaos. We will use the following one which is basically an adaption of Devaney's definition MR1046376 to the setting of strongly continuous semigroups, cf. MR1468101 .

definition A strongly continuous semigroup [MATH_76] on a Banach space [MATH_77] is called chaotic if the following two conditions hold: itemize [ (i) ] There exists an [MATH_78] such that its orbit [MATH_79] is dense in [MATH_80] . (Then the semigroup is called hypercyclic .) [ (ii) ] The set of periodic points [MATH_81] is dense in [MATH_82] . itemize definition

remark remark1 itemize [ (1) ] As with [MATH_83] also the set [MATH_84] is dense, [MATH_85] is necessarily separable. [ (2) ] The orbit of any point [MATH_86] in a dense orbit [MATH_87] is again dense in [MATH_88] . Hence, the set of points with a dense orbit is a dense subset of [MATH_89] . [ (3) ] For a separable Banach space [MATH_90] condition (i) in the definition above is equivalent to topological transitivity of the semigroup [MATH_91] , which means that for any pair of non-empty open subsets [MATH_92] there is a [MATH_93] with [MATH_94] , cf. MR1468101 . [ (4) ] If both subsets [MATH_95] and [MATH_96] are dense in [MATH_97] , the semigroup [MATH_98] has dense orbits. However, this condition is not necessary, cf. MR1468101 . For a more detailed study of sufficient conditions for a strongly continuous semigroups to be hypercyclic we refer to MR2142183,MR2203889,MR2152389,MR2280828,MR2231625,MR2358980 . [ (5) ] Hypercyclic semigroups exist only on infinite dimensional Banach spaces. When looking at the Jordan canonical form of a bounded operator on a (real or complex) finite dimensional Banach space, a proof of this is straightforward, see e.g. [Proposition 11] MR1685272 . On the other hand, on every infinite dimensional separable Banach space exists a hypercyclic semigroup, cf. MR1974641 . [ (6) ] In Devaney's definition of chaotic dynamical systems it was also required that orbits depend sensitively on initial conditions. This property is redundant in this setting, see e.g. MR1157223,MR1111569 . [ (7) ] For results concerning the discrete case we refer to MR2079359,MR1710637,MR1111569,MR1685272,MR2041336 . itemize remark

theorem [ MR1468101 ] thm dsw Let [MATH_99] denote a strongly continuous semigroup on a separable Banach space [MATH_100] with generator [MATH_101] . Furthermore, if for some [MATH_111] we have [MATH_112] then already [MATH_113] holds. itemize Then the semigroup [MATH_114] is chaotic. theorem

Then it follows that the subset [MATH_118] is dense in [MATH_119] . But this is a contradiction.\\ For the subsets [MATH_125] , [MATH_126] , and [MATH_127] it follows now [MATH_128] , [MATH_129] , and [MATH_130] . As all these sets are dense in [MATH_131] , the proof is complete. proof

In the theory of dynamical systems chaotic semigroups are highly unwanted because of their difficult dynamics. Not much more appreciated are so called subspace chaotic semigroups. This notion was introduced in MR2128736 :

definition A strongly continuous semigroup [MATH_132] on a Banach space [MATH_133] is called subspace chaotic if there is a closed, [MATH_134] invariant subspace [MATH_135] of [MATH_136] such that the restriction [MATH_137] is a chaotic semigroup on [MATH_138] . definition

Because of Remark remark1 such a subspace is always infinite dimensional. Banasiak and Moszy\'nski showed that a subset of the conditions in Theorem thm dsw yield a sufficient condition for subspace chaos:

theorem ( [Criterion 3.3] MR2128736 ). thm ban Let [MATH_139] denote a strongly continuous semigroup on a separable Banach space [MATH_140] with generator [MATH_141] . Assume there is an open, connected subset [MATH_142] and a function [MATH_143] such that itemize [ (i) ] [MATH_144] . [ (ii) ] [MATH_145] for all [MATH_146] . [ (iii) ] For all [MATH_147] in the dual space of [MATH_148] , the mapping [MATH_149] is analytic. itemize Then the semigroup [MATH_150] is subspace chaotic.\\ Furthermore, the restriction of [MATH_151] to the [MATH_152] invariant subspace [MATH_153] is chaotic. theorem
Note that it is not required [MATH_154] here, i.e. either [MATH_155] is an eigenvector or [MATH_156] . But, as explained in MR2128736 , the assumption [MATH_157] is not really weaker.\\
Theorem thm dsw and Theorem thm ban will be important ingredients in the proof of our main results in Section section dynamics .

In the rank one case we identified precisely an invariant subspace [MATH_372] on which [MATH_373] is chaotic, in the higher rank case we only know that there is an invariant subspace of [MATH_374] on which the respective semigroup is chaotic. Comparison with symmetric spaces of euclidean or compact type

Any globally symmetric space [MATH_418] is the product [MATH_419] of a symmetric space of non-compact type [MATH_420] , a euclidean space [MATH_421] , and a symmetric space of compact type [MATH_422] which is always compact (see MR514561 ). The aim of this section is to show that such a chaotic dynamics, as in the setting of symmetric spaces of non-compact type, cannot occur in the two other situations.

theorem Let [MATH_423] denote a symmetric space whose factors are a symmetric space [MATH_424] of euclidean type and a symmetric space [MATH_425] of compact type (it is allowed that one of the factors is trivial). Then, for any [MATH_426] and any [MATH_427] the semigroup [MATH_428] is not subspace chaotic. theorem proof The intersection of the point spectrum of the generator of a chaotic semigroup with the imaginary axis is always infinite (see MR1855839 and its erratum). Hence, the theorem follows if we can prove [MATH_429] . To see this, we note that [MATH_430] if [MATH_431] is a euclidean space and [MATH_432] if [MATH_433] is a symmetric space of compact type. As the [MATH_434] spectrum [MATH_435] coincides in these cases with the [MATH_436] spectrum (see e.g. MR1250269 ) and as the [MATH_437] spectrum [MATH_438] of the product [MATH_439] coincides with the sum [MATH_440] (see [Theorem 2.1] Weber:2008ve ) the result follows. proof
